reviewText: The Serious Sam series is some of my favorite FPS games I have ever played. I played the first 2 when they came out and thought why don't more FPS games do this?" Sending hundreds of enemies at you is extremely exhilarating. I never seen any other game do this like the Serious Sam games. You feel amazing as you try to dodge hundreds of enemies and their projectiles all at the same time.\n\nI always thought The Second Encounter was the best in the series
date: until I played this one. It feels a lot more modern and I love how the enemies look when they explode into bits and pieces. They got rid of the annoying trap rooms from TSE (I always thought they were badly designed) and upgraded the level design. The physics engine makes the majority of the levels have breakable walls. This creates some awesome gunfights
recommended: when you have tons of enemies blasting things at you and walls are breaking all around you while you try and shoot back at them.\n\nThe Serious Sam series is also known for their final levels and just how brutal and awesome they can be. Over 1
hoursPlayed: 000 enemies coming at you? Check. Nearly 2 hour level? Check. Huge boss fight at the end of the level? Check. Seriously difficult? Double check. I think this game has the best final level in the series. The music and enemy formations
voteText: just made everything seem so perfect. Good luck ever beating the level on Serious difficulty.\n\nThis game will last you around 15 hours on Normal difficulty. There are other game modes you can play and the real strength of the game comes from playing the Campaign on Serious difficulty. Every FPS fan needs to try this game."

You kill them all.

If you are looking for an all-out slaughterhouse of a game, this is the one.

reviewText: Genre -  FPS (nothing more, nothing less)\nShoot Stuff, do a bit of jumping/collecting and shoot some some more stuff. This game is a straight up FPS in the style of Doom with supported local and network co-op. There are one liners and the creatures you fight add there own dark humour. You can play in short bursts and I haven't found it too frustrating as yet. Although if you don't play in co-op you will not enjoy the game half as much. Please bear in mind that the randoms who play online will probably vote to skip the story cut-scenes, as has happened to me on my first playthrough.

reviewText:
When i first opened Serious Sam 3 BFE i teared up. It was such a beautiful moment that it took me back to the first time i ever played Serious Sam - a unique,unforgettable and exquisite franchise that got me into the FPS genre.
About Sam 'Serious' Stone: There isn't much to be said about Sam Stone, except that he is a total destroyer of  Mental's world. His serious personality has inspired me for so long and now in this prequel of the first encounter i felt his anger and frustration in level 11 when his whole squad was wasted. Oops, spoiler i guess.
Gameplay: You can start playing this game by choosing one of the 3 modes: Single Player, Multiplayer or Versus.
For me the most memorable parts i ever had with this game were in MP. I have never experienced so much carnage and fun that can reach the ridiculous amount of 16 players in co-op. I personally reccommend that you join the steam group called '7smoke'  in order to enjoy online play without any speedrunners. There is also survival mode that throws you into a battle arena of countless waves of enemies.
For those of you who enjoy playing solo, i must warn you. Don't click on 'serious' if you are a newcomer to the franchise.
The final mode is Versus and for me this was a bit of dissapointment in comparison to the brilliant Serious Sam HD: The Second Encounter versus. The double-shotgun is ridiculously overpowered, the maps aren't that good, a lot of rage quit and tons more stuff that annoys me, but still could be fun if you play with the right people.
We must not forget that Serious Sam 3 BFE has full workshop support that has a lot of interesting mods from people that are really creative. So you can play christmas mods during the holidays, halloween events and etc. If you can't find the right map or character skin you want to play with you can create it yourself with the new Serious Editor 3.5.
And to wrap this short review up i must tell you that Serious Sam 3 BFE is an easy 10/10 for me, but only because this is my childhood game and i love every addition to it. For newcomers that have never played Serious Sam before i can recommend this game with all my heart, and hope that this game will have the same impact on you that it had on me.
Stay serious folks !

reviewText:
Is this another typical shooter? Yes and no. The game play and the art style does it's best to differentiate itself from anything else.

I'd like to first mention the fact you can choose a third person view. This game does it's best to give you every option in the book and by simply adding this just means the devs care. One thing about the third person view, when the player backs up into a wall (not facing it), the camera switches to first person view. This is done I'm assuming so we don't get any camera clipping through the walls. It can be annoying, but some will probably find that brilliant.

Whenever there is scenery that can break, or that gives a reaction back when hit, I'm definitely a fan of. Serious Sam has a lot of weapons, some that can be used with variance. The hammer for instance, can break through wooden planks or when X is pressed (on an X-box controller), Sam instead of swinging forward, does a whole ballerina spin to knock everyone out. If Sam hit's a wall, dust comes off it! Not everything breaks, but there is quite a bit you can hit and still get something out of it. Heck, if that sort of close combat melee isn't enough, when an enemy gets close, hit the A button to do a custom melee take down. You even get a trophy to throw once you do this. Weapons are somewhat basic but as the story line progresses, they do as well. All basic movements are given in this game which is absolutely fantastic (sprint, duck, jump). One addition that may have helped would be something as seen in Dishonored, where you can climb certain obstacles. Once in a while, you may find yourself trying to get up a stairwell you simply cannot. It may not seem obvious at first, but after multiple tries you finally realize you were maybe not supposed to go there. The enemies in this game are by far differentiated from the rest of the FPS world. My personal favorite is this guy running with two bombs in his hands, and yells at the top of his lungs as he is approaching you. Most of the time you have no idea where this guy is either than hearing his voice, and it's a scramble to find him. Blood type can also be switched in options. Don't like red? Go green? Don't like green? Go hippie.... (seriously). The game provides quite a challenge on one player and can be very fun on local-coop.

Visuals and sounds are really good. The menu is easy to navigate and brilliantly done. The game's graphics are quite consistent and have not noticed any chopping. Sounds are welcomed as well as dialogue throughout the game. Sam does make a few comments here and there when seeing or dealing with certain enemies. My favorite part I must mention though is the local-coop ability. You can choose to play with 2-4 players and CHOOSE the screen sizes if you are playing with 3 people. Amazing feature once you start playing with friends.

I recommend this game as it has local co-op and is extremely fun with friends. Alone, it can still provide entertainment and still worth a purchase. If this FPS had no local co-op it would be rated as an average shooter at 7.4-7.5. Because of all the added extras, I'll have to give it



RATING : 8.1/10



Gameplay	B	Story / Campaign	B+	Visuals / User Interface	B	Sounds / Music	B	Replay-ability	B	Overall 	B

reviewText:
Faulty's scorecard :-

1) Essential purchase
2) Recommended purchase
3) Recommended purchase during a sale4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors


Croteam is back with yet another Serious Sam title and to be honest I am beginning to care less and less for them with each incremental number that gets added. This title is supposed to act as a prequel to the original Serious Sam remade in all its choppy HD glory a little while back. Yes - the alien invaders still want to annihilate earths human citizens and yes it's up to Sam and friends (if playing in co-op as I believe up to 16 people can join in on the action) to stop them.

Serious Sam 3 does little, very little, to distinguish itself from the other titles in the series and it honestly feels a bit like a cut and paste job with an engine that now supports Direct x11. The feeling of deja vu sets in early with this one since there is hardly anything you haven't already seen in the previous titles. A better enemy variety would have been a welcome change but little is tinkered with here so it's waves upon waves of the same re-spawning enemies from the 1 and 2 episodes with only one or two new additions.

I could never imagine playing this title alone and thankfully I had a friend with me to co-op right through to the end although we never really got to see the end because the game allowed us to pass through to the final boss without picking up a weapon from the previous stage that is required to kill him. Thanks Croteam! Who the hell play-tested your game? That just killed it for us as we promptly both deleted all local content from our drives and packed SS3:BFE away for good.

Although I am sounding very negative about the game I still had fun with it in bursts. The gameplay is still incredibly fast and furious and the Direct x11 enhanced graphics do look rather awesome on a system that can beef up the game in the settings department - but - and its a very big BUT - Croteam are going to have to energize the next chapter should there be one because even for an old school off-the-rails shooter like this one things are starting to feel a little more than stale and tired.

If you enjoyed reading this review please follow my curator group at:-
Curator Rater

reviewText:
I love all the Serious Sam games to date, I used to play them as a child and really enjoyed them, thats why I have a lot of confronted feelings about this game, so here it goes:

++PROS++
-Mindlessly killing hordes of monsters is always fun
-Not serious game/dialogue, funny one-liners

--CONS--
-It gets TOO repetitive. reviewText:
Before the First Encounter (though Battle For Endor sounds much better!) is the 3rd instalment of Croteam's Serious Sam franchise, however, this time the Croatian guys picked the make-it-a-prequel-it-is-catchier road. To be honest, I have no idea what makes it a prequel - story-wise, you still keep shooting at various aliens until every one of them dies.

The concept is similar to what Painkiller has: you walk / run along and enjoy the silence and suddenly you hear loud music indicating the oncoming hordes, and I mean HORDES, of enemies. Once you are done with all of them you can proceed to the next section - by only hearing your footsteps - where everything starts over.

Your guns are big, using them is very enjoyable and none have the option to be reloaded. You just keep pressing the button until you run out of ammo. Oh, and sometimes there are bigger enemies that are meant to be the bosses. Simple as that.

So, the core elements remained the same: it has always been a mindless shooter with Sam trying to sound as cool as Duke Nukem. My opinion is: sometimes he gets it right and sometimes he doesn't.

Unlike previous instalments this game looks stunningly beautiful and even though it is already a 3-year old game it requires some high-end components so that you can enjoy the spectacle of blown up enemies and flying body parts!

For those who love this genre (or more like: subgenre) Serious Sam is a must!

reviewText: Not too often game nowadays: hundreds of enemies with different behaviours and tactics to dodge, evade, and most importantly, shoot. “Serious Sam 3” really stayed true to first and second encounters with its big guns, huge bosses, hordes of monsters, bad-aѕs protagonist, large level with lots of secrets… Original “Sams” borrowed from 90’s classics: “Duke Nukem”-like hero, “Doom”-like gameplay. New instalment added some modern elements like iron sights, stamina-consuming sprinting, cutscenes, etc., but overall it is good old! Latest Masterpiece by Croatian Developer Croteam.The first Serious Sam,as well as its Second Encounter had everything you could want in an FPS;an easy difficulty making you feel invincible - the opposite one teaching you to dodge in realistically deadly scenarios, intense and frantic action with beautiful and detailed level designs and atmosphere, and gigantic environments littered with some crazy secrets.i used to be a veteran player of Serious Sam The Second Encounter/Deathmatch/Coop.
Serious Sam 3 is an old school shooter with fast paced action and hordes of enemies.

Overall: Sam 3 is an amazing game from an indi company-Croteam.This is definitely a good fps game especially for a Single player experience. This game still keeps its old shooter roots while adding few new modern features.So if you are tired of Cod or other modern fps try out Serious Sam 3 for a different experience.

reviewText:
After playing all the Serious Sams and reluctantly finishing the terrible Serious Sam 2, it was great to see that Serious Sam 3 was again more serious than the cartoonyness of SS2.

I enjoyed SS3 mostly, it had a sense of urgency and franticness, and amusing dialogue from Sam, with hordes of enemies to kill.

I liked the improved graphics.
Hordes of enemies to kill especially in the 2nd half of the game you get insane amounts thrown at you.
Sams Humorous dialogue, which made me laugh or at least amuse me most of the time.
Like that you can melee enemies and rip out their eyes, hearts and can use them as a weapon against other enemies.

I dislike that it can feel very repetitive and tiresome, especially the last level, it just dragged on and on.
It's easy to get lost and confused on lvls, I had to replay lvls just so I could beat it in half the time.

Overall I had fun and enjoyed playing this game.

I recommend it and rate it 7/10.

reviewText:
Personal Rating: 7 of 10

First off, excellent graphics style upgrade since SS:TFE and SS:TSE (HD). This is how I always visualized Serious Sam should be and not the cartoonish SS2 which did not make it into the limelight. If you've played the previous installment you will pretty much get the idea of this game. Hordes of monsters and variety of arsenal at your dispose. Cheesy dialog and tonnes of lead and gore.

The game stick to its root but added some interesting weapons and features and a dash of new enemies, which in my opinion is just nice.

Controls are fluid and the soundtrack is, well, annoying as usual with the rock solid sound effect. Up until now, there are still some servers running with a pinch of community playing co-op game but unfortunately for me, I wasn't in the US so ping was horrible.

If you are just getting this game for its single player mode, my advice is take it slow and steady. One step at a time will get you there.

reviewText: This might be the best single-player first person shooter ever. I'm not even kidding. Start on hard or higher and never ever touch the quicksave/quickload keys.\n\nThe beginning of the game kinda sucks in that the enemies you fight are super easy and it takes a little bit to get out of the usual corridor-shooting stuff, but all was forgiven after about half an hour. The variety in enemy behavior, the variety in weapon usage, the constantly-changing arenas, the constantly changing visibility, the perfectly rationed ammo and health pickups, and the tension added to the game when you can't quicksave all mash together and make the big fights in this game wonderful.

reviewText:
Unless you're a die-hard fan who yearns for new experiences after having played every other Serious Sam, don't get this.
Buy the Second Encounter of the Serious Sam games instead.

BFE adds features to the series like putting a dung heap into your favorite pie recipe which creates an extremely irritating parody/mocking of the previous games. These features include sprinting, ironsights, weapons that suddenly have to use magazines, hitscan enemys and a really bad melee system.
Some small-minded fanboy might say that I have the option not to use any of these but it is clear as day other aspects of the game had been changed to fit around your great new features".

Sprinting allows you to walk faster forwards at the cost of not being able to shoot. Running and gunning always had been the core functionality of the game so this is a genius move. Optionality is not a counter-argument since enemy speeds have been increased to "counteract" the sprinting ability
date:
making enemys such as Kleer annoying to deal with because they have 200 meter jumps which normally ended up in good shotgun range but now make a succesful dodge half as rewarding.

Weapon magazines on the Tier 1 Shotgun and M4 are there to slow down your fast paced shooter and make sure you enjoy your time actively doing absolutely nothing.

The increased amount/strength of hitscan enemys ensures your run and gun fast paced shooter turns into a blow-trading cover based waiting-simulator. While the previous games had hitscan enemys that would instantly shoot on sight but have poor long-range capabilities the ones in this game have to be baited to shoot after which you wait out their shooting behind cover until you can return fire. Rinse and repeat with a lot of waiting. Waiting is fun I enjoy it a lot thank you.

The bad melee system allows you to instantkill certain enemys once you are close enough at the cost of being locked in a killing animation(it won't look satisfying the 2000th you do it I can promise you that). More waiting
recommended: thanks a lot. I would truly let this "feature" slide if it wasn't for the fact its the only way to get rid of the new giant bug enemy type which is merely a bullet sponge. It is less frustrating to use the melee instantkill on them en masse and works (it shouldn't) because their AI does not have a proper reaction to close quarters combat with the player.\n\nGraphics are grey
hoursPlayed: mediocre and uninteresting. Enemy designs have been reduced to tones of grey and red. For some reason the Doom mancubus is in this.\n\nOn the good side
voteText: the second half of the game gets slightly better as it attempts to ape the previous games. If you can wade through the first half
helpfulPercent: that is.\nThe music is also nice I guess."

reviewText:
This is a long review, so if you want a brief summary of why I recommend this game skip to Results and read from there.

Croteam continues the epic saga that is Serious Sam pushing the foundations why this game tests time. Serious Sam 3: BFE is a brilliant rendition of all the elements that made this game so seriously epic.

Story:
Serious Sam 3: BFE is a prequel to the Serious Sam The First Encounter. The world is under attack by Mental and his forces as Sam and his team must retrieve research data behind the Sirian weapon system that could be the key behind defeating the world’s most devastating foe. As all of Sam’s comrades fall and he pushes the forces of Mental down one by one the world falls into dust and it would seem all is lost. Using his trusty comrade Netrisca Sam is able to solve the Sirian puzzle and land right where Serious Sam The First Encounter Begins.

Campaign:
Serious Sam 3: BFE is divided into twelve levels that gradually increase in length. The levels start out rather short, but extend in length lasting reaching over an hour and a half each. There are six difficulties which scale brilliantly: Tourist, Easy, Medium, Hard, Serious, and Mental. Beating the campaign on Serious unlocks Mental difficulty, which adds a whole new element to the campaign. Even on Serious Difficulty you will essentially be slaughtering waves of enemies that will fall to your feet as if you were a wolf amongst lambs… The sea will run red with the blood of your enemies!!! The easier the difficulty the more ridiculous the slaughter will be, depending on how you play you may enjoy the easier skills. The campaign has epic puzzles and brilliant boss fights that keep you on the edge of your seat. Most of the bosses throughout the game are mostly just regular enemies that are slightly stronger; although, two of the bosses Ugh-Zan IV and Alcor Class Warship are brilliant new editions to the game that relate to the original story.

Gameplay:
Serious Sam 3: BFE follows suit with the other games in the series. You play a complete and total bad ♥♥♥ modeled after a 80s action hero as you defeat thousands upon thousands of enemies. The game boasts fifteen weapons: Fists, Sledgehammer, Axe, Sirian Mutilator, SOP38 Pistol, 12 Gauge Pump-Action Shotgun, Double Barrel Coach Gun, M29 Infantry Assault Rifle, XM-214-A Minigun, XPML21 Rocket Launcher, XL2 Lasergun, AS-24 Devastator, RAPTOR Sniper Rifle, C-4 Demolition Charge, and SBC Cannon. The combinations of epic weapons give you a huge diversity of methods to defeat the mass enemies that are ahead of you.

Jewel of the Nile DLC:
Jewel of the Nile is a fantastic addition to Serious Sam 3 BFE. This addition changes the dynamic of SS3 BFE by changing the game from a mass shooter to puzzle solving. The levels resemble more of a DOOM or Shadow Warrior style where you will be finding secrets and solving puzzles. The DLC includes three levels: Gathering of the Gods, Together Forever, and Born Again. These levels make the secret weapons more available and the jetpack from the final boss fight a featured element. This DLC offers amazing new features and includes epic boss fights to boot.

Hints:
>I would recommend looking up where to find the secret XL2 Lasergun and ammo as if you don’t you probably won’t get to use it.
>I would recommend looking up where to find the secret RAPTOR Sniper Rifle and ammo as if you don’t you probably won’t get to use it.
>I would recommend looking up where to find the secret SBC Cannon because it’s just fun to use, although you will get it later in the game.

Results:
Serious Sam 3: BFE continues the brilliance of the series by pushing the foundation of the original and only making the series that much greater. I would recommend getting this game even if it’s at full price. With DLC added you and Steam Workshop support this game offers more than you could image. SS3: BFE plays like an 80s action movie where you play an amazing hero who runs in guns blazing and kills thousands of enemies while only getting minor scratches.

Pros:
+With fifteen different weapons you will never be bored.
+Twelve fantastic levels that are all unique and incorporate new features and elements.
+Many different enemies, some new some old, that keep you at check.
+Loads of secrets that increase replay value and make you want to scour the levels.
+A jetpack for the final boss battle making taking Sam to all new levels (get it, because he can fly)
+So much nostalgia, so much feels.

Cons:
-Some of the weapons are secret and you will not get to use them if you don’t find them.
-The sun shines into your eyes essentially blinding you at certain points in the campaign.

reviewText:
If you weren't already convinced on the Serious Sam Series (from reading my previous review on Serious Sam Classic: The First Encounter), then you should listen up.

While this, the newest game in the franchise, may not be as stable, it brings a lot of new elements to the table.
This includes new enemies, some hard to kill, others easier, instant melee attacks exclusive to each enemy, some that instantly kill them, but leave you vulnerable for up to about four seconds, new weapon designs, brilliant level design, even more insane waves of enemies, revamped graphics (that go well with the HD versions of the classic games), a ♥♥♥♥ing sledgehammer, alien helicopters, Sam with gloves, co-op play, one billion secrets, 120% more one-liners relating The Artist Formerly known as Prince and also that loud growl that comes on when a boss or a horde of enemies attacks you.

TL,DR; Two thumbs WAY up.

reviewText:
Serious Sam 3: BFE is a first-person shooter video game developed by Croteam and published by Devolver Digital. It is part of the Serious Sam series and a prequel to The First Encounter. The game's story takes place in the 22nd century, during Mental's invasion of Earth, as implied in The First Encounter. The game is set in Egypt and features a 16-player co-operative campaign mode, as well as 4-player splitscreen. The game was released on November 22, 2011 on Windows, October 17, 2012 on Xbox Live Arcade, while the PlayStation 3 version was released on May 13, 2014.

Like previous titles in the series, Serious Sam 3: BFE involves fighting against many hordes of enemies in wide-open environments. However Serious Sam 3 has more closed environments than its predecessors, particularly in the early levels. There are also a larger number of enemies that can attack the player from a distance.

The player can carry an unlimited amount of weapons, including a minigun, rocket launcher, assault rifle and a cannon. There are 13 weapons total. 5 of them have a manual reload. The signature close-combat weapons from the first game, the knife and chainsaw, have been replaced with a sledgehammer with three modes of attack (vertical strike, 180 turn and full 360 turn).

When I said the 360, I know you first thought of 360 Spin, also, no scope :)))))))

There is no regenerating health, instead there are health and armor power-ups scattered throughout the levels that the player must pick up. Additionally, the levels are full of secret areas, where health, armor, ammo and in some cases, weapons from later levels can be found, following the tradition of the previous games. Some weapons such as the Lasergun and the Sniper Rifle and their respective ammunition pickups are in fact secret-only, and otherwise are not found in the levels normally. There are no puzzles, however the player must find keys, pull levers and find environmental anomalies to progress.

Classic enemies such as the Beheaded Kamikaze, Beheaded Rocketeer and Kleer Skeleton return in the game. New ones include the Khnum and Scrapjack (resembling the Hell Knight and Mancubus from Doom, respectively), as well as the cloned soldiers reminiscent of the Strogg from the Quake series. The Kamikaze has returned to his original design, rather than the Serious Sam II design. The Gnaar's design has radically been changed from the original game. It is now much larger, differently shaped and walks on all fours, unlike its bipedal counterpart in Serious Sam.

Rate: 11/10

reviewText: While taking no serious risks to stand unique to them, Serious Sam 3 is a sharp improvement from its predecessors in every aspect. It holds the honor as the definitive Serious Sam game and the definitive old school shooter of this generation, with the only possible contestants to dethrone the latter honor being the recent Shadow Warrior, the upcoming Doom 4 and the series own upcoming sequel Serious Sam 4.

reviewText:
Ah, SS3. Here's the tl;dr:

=======
(steamfriend): so I really dunno wtf to do in SS games.
OOO67VH: kill ♥♥♥♥
=======

Now, the review.  ----- 6/10 above average, barely -----  Thank you, Steam Friend, for prompting this review.

This review is for those who don't know Sam and haven't played the other SS games.

Unlike Sanctum2, Borderlands2, Team Fortress 2, Killing Floor, Left 4 Dead 2 (differentiated characters co-op), Serious Sam 3 is essentially:

- wildly killing things.

In co-op, add these astonishing features:

- several people running around;
- i think they're killing things too;
- dying;
- running back to kill more things.

Sure, it's similar to Sanctum 2 or Borderlands 2 in that regard. It's snarky, like BL2. That's always a plus.

But there is a sense of teamwork in other games. Kiting (leading on a baddie to get his back turned to another shooter). Specialization. One-two punches. Syncopating bullet storms.

One, new to co-op, might wander in SS3 to a point where one is both lost and seeing zero baddies, and the game might stay that way for that person for 5 minutes. Lost, with 'fighting sounds somewhere over there'. That's silly.

Here's the rub: there's absolutely zero incentive for others to notice, much less find the team and fight together. In 2013, that's also silly.

Killing Floor/Left 4 Dead 2, OTOH, on Hard, requires that every single member take turns syncopate a bullet storm, have multitasking medics, for the entire team to survive.

Don't get me wrong. I enjoy it, though. SS3 is a fast-paced shoot-everything-that-moves game.

It, like the other SS, has zero active story and purpose. It's like the original DOOM. The goal is to kill ♥♥♥♥ to get to a key, which unlocks a door, so that you can get to kill more ♥♥♥♥.

DOOM reference!

Co-op SS3 means only that more baddies are on-screen and more people are coincidentally playing in the same general map.

I have bought it for a few friends. I did the same with Borderlands 2, Sanctum 2, and Killing Floor. We play the living hell out of those games. We've played SS3 just once, I think.

But I've played it for hours on solo.

It's fun. But it knows its place in gaming. So should you, before you buy it.

Better value than easily half the movies I've ever rented.

Here goes my first attempt at a serious" review. Serious Sam 3 has great gunplay and customization.

That being said there were several questionable choices made by the developers such as:

date: tons of hitscan and lame monsters like the technopolip a person might get the wrong idea about the game in general. Later it's a lot better though. Sad because the other Sams are fun the whole way.\n\n-Enemy trickle effect: Lets slowly let enemies pile into the playing field instead of doing them in nice clear waves so players get bored standing there killing 1-3 at a time. Okay. Yeah this speaks for itself
recommended: super annoying. Last level this is SUPER awful and annoying. Artificially extends the game length like a half hour at least.\n\n-Default Performance settings: Are all horrible
hoursPlayed: to get any kind of FPS out of the game unless your computer is crazy (and mine pretty good) you have to tweak settings a bit. Average Joe gamer is okay with 45 fps but he's usually on a console w/30 fps anyways. This is PC gaming and you should have your midrange presets giving midrange pcs 60+

reviewText:
Good FPS with old school approach. I played the First and Second Encounter when younger and recently the HD version in coop, the 3rd uses the same formula and is competent in offering an arcade FPS which the goal is to shoot everything that moves with big guns.

The gameplay is simple, advance through the scenario wiping out hordes of enemies that have their peculiarities, for those who played the first the nostalgia is inevitable when hearing a characteristic scream. The new engine can deliver good graphics and visuals, but at a cost, the game is a bit poorly optimized, the mechanics are basically the same with minor additions. There is no plot, just a context, the emphasis is for the badass personality of the protagonist.

It is a simple and brainless shooter, I recommend playing in coop because tends to get boring over the time.

7/10

reviewText:
What can i say? One of the best games i'v played in a while and imo i think it's one of the best fps games of this modern generation.
This game is pretty much everything duke nukem forever should of been.
The music is good but sort of lazy because they re use some of the tracks.
The graphics are good.
Gameplay is great and story as well.
Level design not so much to be honest.
This game is pretty much a huge retro throwback to the classics like Doom,shadow warrior,duke nukem 3d,and more.
Is it the best serious sam game?
To be honest i enjoyed serious sam the second encounter a lot more but that's just my opinion.
Anyways i say 10/10

reviewText:
the most serious game ever made no joke lol
well this is the 3rd game in the serious sam series but the plot tells what happens before the first game ( how did sam travel to the past), BFE stand for before the first encounter which means chronologically it's the first game in the series, so i recommend you to play this one first then go get the first and second encounter HD remake then serious sam 2 to understand the entire plot .
-graphicly it's really beautiful and stunning (runs on serious engine 3.5) run it on ultra and still got 60fps .
-gameplay is a bit different from old serious sam games , this time you can reload your weapons also new type of weapon ( melee and new pistol ,new shotgun ,rifle...ect ) and new bosses, new game mod online or co op and split screen , funny moments , easter eggs and reference are present in this episode too but the game get sometimes really hard until it becomes ridiculous especially the last one where you have to fight 1740 monster )
-as always the voice acting is excellent , metal music , great sound effects
-online game is good , alot of mods for co op or versus but sadly not a lot of people are playing it so you will find the servers most of the times empty ( doesnt help when you want to get achievements except if you have friends that have the game too)
-no bugs or glitches ( the devs update the game each time they find something isn't working right)
-most of the achievements are easy to get but others are a bit hard cause they are only obtained by playing online and not a lot of people are playing it
-steam trading cards.
i highly recommend this game for those who want a serious hardcore challenging game ( if not you just play on easy ) and get the dlcs too (they offer some good extras and a good solo campaign (3h of gameplay) ) worth the money but you can grab it on sales ( dlcs on sales are 0.99$  )
9/10

reviewText: Serious Sam 3; BFE (Before First Encounter) is probably one of the best games Croteam ever made! The game offers Single Player and Multiplayer game modes,with both are fun,full of violence,gore,awesome catchphrases and of course great animations! The multiplayer doesn't lag,well at least for me. Best parts of the Single Player campaign (and cooperative) are the cool melee attacks! One moment you are ripping a Gnaars eye,and the other breaking Scorpions necks! Double Barrel shotgun is the perfect tool in blowing some in too two billion pieces! Playing multiplayer is awesome for trolling with the Sledgehammer or the DBShotgun! For all Serious Sam fans,this is the perfect game to buy,and DLC is worth the money too! Finding out what lead to The First Encounter is great. The sound,the graphics and the videos are PERFECTLY DONE! THIS GAME IS RECOMMENDED TO EVERYONE! WELL DONE CROTEAM AND WELL DONE DEVOLVER DIGITAL! YOU MADE A MASTER PIECE!

reviewText:
Game Play: 1st person shooter. Kill everything you see. Carry all the weapons you picked up.

Map design: Linear. Maps are huge. Serious Sam series contain the largest map of any FPS. Serious Sam 3: BFE is no exception.

How Long To Beat It: Around 22 hours on normal single player.

Difficulties On Normal: Very few can solo it on normal . Even on easy it is extremely hard to solo.

Kids Rating: Violence. Lots of blood. Swearing. Nudity.

Bugs: Crashed one or twice.

Game Control: Standard.

Save System: Check Point, Auto, and Manual Save System. You can save the game at anytime and anywhere. No limit on save files. Manual save keep the frustration level down.

Option Menu: Full control of video and audio.

Recommend Buying Price: $5 or lower for general public. $25 or lower for players that loves very hard old style FPS shooter.

---
I've beaten all three Serious Sam games. Serious Sam 1 is the hardest follow by Serious Sam 3: BFE, and finally Serious Sam 2. Even experts FPS players will have a hard time soloing any Serious Sam games. However in co-ops it is beatable for most players.

Serious Sam 3 provide the same classic weapons of it predecessors. From pistol to rocket launcher to cannon balls and everything in between. Like its predecessors you can carry and use all the weapons you pick up. There is no weapon carry limit.

The basic game play in all Serious Sam game is the survival of the mob rush. Hundreds of enemies some of them the size of skyscraper will be barreling down on you. Surviving these constant attacks is hard and harder at the end of the game.

Not many players can solo Serious Sam games. The alternative way of beating Serious Sam game is to go co-op. Co-op reduce the difficulties and frustration.

reviewText:
The sequel that Serious Sam: The Second Encounter deserves.

Serious Sam 3 drops lifes system and toy guns of Serious Sam 2, and brings the crazy over-the-top action back into the series. Some new additions help the game feel fresh, such as a sledgehammer, and enemy-specific melee attacks. You can also complain about the CoD-like sprinting and iron-sights mechanics until you're blue in the face, but theres no denying that they make the game more fast paced and frantic.

The campaign can also be played co-op with up to 16 players, and the versus multiplayer is still as addictive and balanced as ever.

Somewhat poor optimization here and there, but overall, Serious Sam 3 is one of the most complete and accessible games in the series to date. If you're not a fan of the series, this won't change your mind. But for eveyone else, give it a try.

reviewText: While at a glance, this game looks like another generic brown and grey shooter and Croteam completely sold out to appease the COD crowd, this game is absolutley like it's predecessors. Sure you can sprint for an indifinite period of time, and you can  aim down sights (I actually really like ADS), but rest assured, everything about this game is Serious Sam. You still fight hordes upon hordes upon hordes of enemies while utilizing a metric ♥♥♥♥ton of weaponry in gigantic environments. I'm not sure whether the modern city environments were either a send up to modern shooters or in fact a very clever message about the state of shooters today though. Multiplayer is pretty cool. There weren't too many people playing versus, so I didn't get the chance to try that out. Co-op on the other hand... You can have up to 16 people playing. While the most I've ever gotten to try out was 8 people (unfortunately, not very many people play multiplayer at all in this game), it was still an absolute blast having so many people contribute to a mindless violent orgy. This game is also quite well optimized, as I get a consitent 30 FPS on my craptop. Ths game is also on the 360, where I played the game's splitscreen (the PC version also has splitscreen, a very commendable move on Croteam's part) with a friend of mine who happens to be a big fan of COD, but is still very willing to try new things. I don't think I've ever heard him laughing so hard mindlessly mutilating enemies with miniguns and killer jewlery. The PC version also has excellent gamepad support, something more PC games should have. The only real issue I have with this game is it's pacing. It takes about 2 to 3 levels for the game to finally hit it's stride. Sure, this a sequence in the first level that reminds you that this is a Serious Sam game, but the next level is without a doubt, the weakest level in the entire game, if not the entire series. But after that travesty, the rest of the game picks up, and when it picks up, it's one hell of a ride. I would absolutely recommend this to anyone and everyone who is a fan of shooting things until they expire. Great game, thanks.

reviewText: While at a glance, this game looks like another generic brown and grey shooter and Croteam completely sold out to appease the COD crowd, this game is absolutley like it's predecessors. Sure you can sprint for an indifinite period of time, and you can  aim down sights (I actually really like ADS), but rest assured, everything about this game is Serious Sam. You still fight hordes upon hordes upon hordes of enemies while utilizing a metric ♥♥♥♥ton of weaponry in gigantic environments. I'm not sure whether the modern city environments were either a send up to modern shooters or in fact a very clever message about the state of shooters today though. Multiplayer is pretty cool. There weren't too many people playing versus, so I didn't get the chance to try that out. Co-op on the other hand... You can have up to 16 people playing. While the most I've ever gotten to try out was 8 people (unfortunately, not very many people play multiplayer at all in this game), it was still an absolute blast having so many people contribute to a mindless violent orgy. This game is also quite well optimized, as I get a consitent 30 FPS on my craptop. Ths game is also on the 360, where I played the game's splitscreen (the PC version also has splitscreen, a very commendable move on Croteam's part) with a friend of mine who happens to be a big fan of COD, but is still very willing to try new things. I don't think I've ever heard him laughing so hard mindlessly mutilating enemies with miniguns and killer jewlery. The PC version also has excellent gamepad support, something more PC games should have. The only real issue I have with this game is it's pacing. It takes about 2 to 3 levels for the game to finally hit it's stride. Sure, this a sequence in the first level that reminds you that this is a Serious Sam game, but the next level is without a doubt, the weakest level in the entire game, if not the entire series. But after that travesty, the rest of the game picks up, and when it picks up, it's one hell of a ride. I would absolutely recommend this to anyone and everyone who is a fan of shooting things until they expire. Great game, thanks.

reviewText: When all is said and done, Serious Sam 3 is just plain refreshing. It's nice to have a game that relies so much on flat-out enemy decimation, and which does it so well, so beautifully, and while providing at least the opportunity to share the experience with friends online. If you're weary of todays high profile first person shooters and their endless hype, Serious Sam 3's endless enemies and endless ammo are the perfect antidote. Serious Sam 3 is a game that deserves to be played, because it shows what shooters were and could have been. It shows that there's more to the genre than what AAA developers have shown us in the past decade.Pure mayhem, pure fun, pure Serious Sam, pure first-person shooting.

reviewText:
Serious Sam 3: BFE is a brutal shooter set in Cairo, featuring Sam having to deal with a breakout of rampaging aliens.

PROS:
+ Quite long gameplay (easily 10 hours on just singleplayer)
+ Awesome unimaginably overlord weaponry, as well as a decent variety in weapons to use
+ Great dose of humor
+ Nice graphics
+ There is LOTS to shoot. Thousands of enemies per level if not
+ Elimination of annoying physics like recoil (that's right, there's no recoil or spread)
+ The multiplayer co-op is actively visited and servers are always availabe for both BFE campaign and the DLC campaign
+ Tons of secret areas and hidden items
+ Expandable with DLC
+ Bonus material available (OST, concept art, making of" videos
date:
etc.)
+ Trading cards

CONS:
- Gameplay is a lot the same
recommended: except for the changing locations and areas\n- The story is very generic and cliché
hoursPlayed: but that's due this game revolving around the shooting massacre and is done somewhat on purpose\n- For a game that has a lot of secrets that you often have to jump and climb to
voteText: the jumping in BFE is pretty terrible\n- Although it does have pretty good music
helpfulPercent: it has very little variety in it\n\nA prequel to a classic and beloved series of FPS
votesHelpful: set in a somewhat arcade style. A must for anyone who enjoys action and shooters in general.\n\nMy rating: 8.5/10"

For that purpose, wield a 10 round Desert Eagle, a coachgun that can blast most enemies in one hit, a normal assault rifle, or a minigun and turn them into Alien hamburger meat". If a gun doesn't work
date: then use an ancient bracelet and make enemies explode from the inside-out.\n\nCo-op is satisfying and it was very fun to play with a couple of buddies. Unlike some games
recommended: there is a "compass" in which it will inform you where and how far your pals are. This is very helpful when scouting around for hidden areas or to provide support. Once you experience SS 3 with a trusted friend
hoursPlayed: you don't ever want to go solo (again).\n\nSerious Sam 3: BFE did have some disappointing qualities. The level design is not impressive (especially for the underground ruins). Newcomers

reviewText:
Serious Sam 3 is a fantastic game don't get me wrong. But upon retrospect the game really comes across as a squandered opportunity.

The biggest issue I have with this game is it takes place in Egypt. The location of the first game. Having the game be a prequel to the first game really didn't make any sense to me, and I believe 3 would have been significantly stronger if they made it take place in a different location.

This was something Serious Sam 2 oddly enough was stronger with. Serious Sam 2 took place in Alien locations that contrasted the Egypt and Jungle/Arctic/Medieval maps from TFE and TSE.

In general the game is fine and a necessary improvement over the HD games. But I really wish Croteam took more risks with this game.

reviewText:
This is the game.
Serious Sam 3: BFE (Before First Encounter)
The prequel to one of the best games on the planet so far.
Follow Sam 'Serious' Stone on his journey through future Egypt, as Sam shoots, explodes, bludgeons & even tear his enemies to shreds with his bare hands.
This game features intense skill-based combat against intelligent AI who will get faster, smarter and as a result more dangerous.
Beat the game on Serious difficulty? You should try MENTAL difficulty argueable one of the most difficult difficulties in gaming so far. Enemies won't only be smart they'll also turn invisable for several seconds & re-appear making the already hard game almost crippling.

If you are not able to handle the difficulty don't fret you can set the game to Tourist" difficult in-order to experience the game's story line & fun game mechanics

Another thing worth mentioning is every weapon in the game is satisfying to use even the little pistol you fire has a bit of "Umph" to it as you fire it
date: some weapons such as the Double Barrel Shotgun work well on enemies like Kleers but it's slow re-load time makes it un-reliable in fire fights where constant fire is required.\n\nThe Multiplayer on the other hand is unbalanced at best
recommended: what it boils down to is: Who has the best gun
hoursPlayed:
and even still it's still has some cheap shots in it.

Other than that this game is up to 16 Player Co-operative mode which is insanely fun to play with freinds.

This game gets a big yes from me and everyone should try it."
voteText: December 19, 2013

reviewText:
I'm confused why this game isn't very popular in Steam, while Left 4 Dead 2 had a huge success. Serious Sam 3 is like the HD version of Left 4 Dead 2 with increased thrill and gore in the game. Plus you'll smash alien with sledgehammers here rather than shooting zombies. Of course, I can't compare L4D2 with Serious Sam 3 since the base concept of the game is totally different. But both of these are Co-Op games. And both of them gave me the same amount of fun when I play with my own friends. Anyway, here's my review :
1.Graphics
Stunning graphics with intense amount of blood and gore along the game. Almost every aspect of the graphics beautifully made in this game. The only downside was the crude animation when the characters speak.
2.Sound
I love the soundtracks ! It really fits your situation in the game and the music changes each time you're in a new situation.
3.Gameplay
Thrilling, fun, and challenging. I can't even survive the Normal difficulty after playing FPS for 14 years. I'm also not new to the gameplay style, since I played Serious Sam : The First and The Second Encounter Co-Op with my dad when I was 6 years old. The health and armor supply in the map is really low that you have to fight really carefully to conserve your HP and armor.
4.Pricing
Honestly,it's not really expensive. Your money will really worth it and you'll get what you pay for. There's only 1 DLC and the game is 100% non pay to win. Buy it.

reviewText:
Serious Sam 3 is a fantastic game don't get me wrong. But upon retrospect the game really comes across as a squandered opportunity.

The biggest issue I have with this game is it takes place in Egypt. The location of the first game. Having the game be a prequel to the first game really didn't make any sense to me, and I believe 3 would have been significantly stronger if they made it take place in a different location.

This was something Serious Sam 2 oddly enough was stronger with. Serious Sam 2 took place in Alien locations that contrasted the Egypt and Jungle/Arctic/Medieval maps from TFE and TSE.

In general the game is fine and a necessary improvement over the HD games. But I really wish Croteam took more risks with this game.

reviewText:
So many great homages to classic First Person Shooters have come out recently, with Shadow Warrior, Hard Reset, Wolfenstein: The New Order, Rise of The Triad etc... So, what makes Serious Sam 3 stand out from the rest?

Well, here are a few reasons: This game is perfect for playing with a friend. The whole game of Serious Sam revolves around you plaing in huge, open-ended enviornments, mowing down wave after wave of literally hundreds of enemies. Playing by yourself is intense, challenging, and down-right panic enducing. With a friend, the intensity is doubled, and the fun factor just shoots through the roof. Trying to separate the waves of enemies into two different targets is really challenging, and it feels even more satisfying when you've got a buddy.

The game's also down-right hilarious. The developers and writers knew what kind of game they were making, and they don't take themselves seriously at all. The game rags on itself, common action movie tropes, practically anything related to action movies in general.

The weapons are just straight-up badass. They even have a double-barreled shotgun (DooM's famous Super Shotgun") that feels just like the classic iteration. Some of the weapons are down-right wacky - like the canonball launcher
date: which literally flattens hundreds of enemies at a time. The gunplay feels solid
recommended: and you feel like you can dole out some serious damage-- a thing that's lacking from a lot of modern-day FPS.\n\nThe amount of customization in the PC version is stellar
hoursPlayed: too. You can honestly get lost in the graphics settings menu. Seriously
voteText: more PC games need to take a hint from Croteam and allow this lush
helpfulPercent: rich level of customization options.\n\nI love classic First Person Shooters quite a bit
votesHelpful: and I guess that's why I'm even more happy with this product. I'll be putting tons of hours into it before DooM comes out. I also highly recommend you check out the other games listed at the top of my review
votesTotal: but pick this one up first and go blow up some monsters.\n"

reviewText:
If you are getting tired of the modern FPS formula, that is a two weapon limit, regenerating health, cover based shooting, etc., the Serious Sam games have always been great for taking a break. Serious Sam 3: BFE has all the old school styled FPS traits: holding an arsenal of weapons at once, fast paced projectile dodging, and exploring all the levels for any secrets you can find. It also has the frantic Serious Sam combat that makes these games so fun, with lots and lots and lots and lots and lots of enemies attacking you at the same time. It may sound unfair, but you're built like a tank, and it's a welcome change of pace from new-school's realistic-ish, combat with a couple of enemies hiding behind cover kind of gameplay. Especially when you co-op it with friends, it is a lot of fun to dodge through enemy rockets and fireballs while laying waste to hundreds of aliens.

It does have it's flaws though. While this is certainly not the kind of game you play for the story, the story is very weak with too many cheesy lines for it's own good. Also, besides some execution kills you can perform on weaker enemies, it doesn't add much to the established gameplay of the other Serious Sam titles, and that's probably not really possible with an old-school styled FPS. Most unforgiveable though, the first impressions on the game are not that great, with the first two or three levels having few enemies and an overall closed in level design. Give it some time though, the levels will open up and it will start barraging you with aliens to slaughter.

If you don't take yourself too seriously (pun intended) and are a bit tired of the common cover based shooting, this game is good for some fast paced, old school macho action.

reviewText:
This is the game.
Serious Sam 3: BFE (Before First Encounter)
The prequel to one of the best games on the planet so far.
Follow Sam 'Serious' Stone on his journey through future Egypt, as Sam shoots, explodes, bludgeons & even tear his enemies to shreds with his bare hands.
This game features intense skill-based combat against intelligent AI who will get faster, smarter and as a result more dangerous.
Beat the game on Serious difficulty? You should try MENTAL difficulty argueable one of the most difficult difficulties in gaming so far. Enemies won't only be smart they'll also turn invisable for several seconds & re-appear making the already hard game almost crippling.

If you are not able to handle the difficulty don't fret you can set the game to Tourist" difficult in-order to experience the game's story line & fun game mechanics

Another thing worth mentioning is every weapon in the game is satisfying to use even the little pistol you fire has a bit of "Umph" to it as you fire it
date: some weapons such as the Double Barrel Shotgun work well on enemies like Kleers but it's slow re-load time makes it un-reliable in fire fights where constant fire is required.\n\nThe Multiplayer on the other hand is unbalanced at best
recommended: what it boils down to is: Who has the best gun
hoursPlayed:
and even still it's still has some cheap shots in it.

Other than that this game is up to 16 Player Co-operative mode which is insanely fun to play with freinds.

This game gets a big yes from me and everyone should try it."

reviewText:
It takes a long time for Serious Sam 3 to feel like a proper Serious Sam game. You get the impression that it started out as a different game (specifically a military shooter) that later became a Serious Sam at some point. As a result, you'll spend upwards of three hours in weird, awkward urban environments shooting assault rifles at mutants. It's not fun, but it doesn't last forever, and gradually, the game reintroduces the increasingly large armies of bizarre enemies that Serious Sam is known for.

Once it gets there, it's pretty good. I enjoyed it more than Serious Sam: The Second Encounter, or Serious Sam 2, but there's still something... off-putting about it. I don't think Croteam quite has a bead on what made the first Serious Sam game so fun. You're constricted a little too much, the objectives sometimes feel a bit too complex for this type of game, and it takes itself just a tad too seriously. I know, right?

Though I guess I prefer this game's tone to the how other Serious Sam sequels feel like cartoons, so  the fact it takes itself so seriously might not actually be a negative.

It's also HARD. I had more trouble finishing this game on normal difficulty than any of the other Serious Sam games. The final gauntlet throws an almost offensive number of very tough, very big enemies at you. In spite of this, the final boss himself is a bit of a let down.

As is the case with most Serious Sam games, it's probably way more fun in co-op.

reviewText:
For each step taken forward, another step was taken back.

Serious Sam 3, where do we begin with you? I grew up playing all of the Serious Sam games, starting from the very beginning. I've played most of the spin-off games as well, along with that god awful GBA port. I'll say as much; Serious Sam 3: BFE, is probably my least favorite game out of the main series. It doesn't mean it was bad, but it certainly needs a retrospective in the development of the next game.

Serious Sam is, for all intents and purporses, a parody game of the gratituous action flicks of the 80s and 90s. Unlike Duke and his bravado of being an unflappable badass, Serious Sam opts to take a more corny approach. He comes off more like Ash from the movie Army of Darkness than John Matrix from Commando. Full of self-references and indulgence for making quips about the ridiculousness of it all, peppered with plenty of black comedy, it works wonderfully by itself.

Serious Sam 3 does get plenty of what made the original games did right. The guns feel fantastic, Sam is still a talkative hardass and most of the classic enemies have returned, with some minor changes. Running jokes, running and gunning, it's all great fun. The graphics are stellar and everything feels crisp. In games like these, the plot takes a backseat to the gameplay at hand, and for good reason. All we know is that Sam's gotta bust an alien army and save the world, that's it. Anything else acts as a transition between levels and sets up the scene. When it comes to controlling, there is only one flaw I can think of and it pertains to Sam's unusually heavy jumping, making platforming somewhat of a hassle.

Despite staying true to the original Serious Sam, specifically the First Encounter, it is ultimately the biggest flaw - it stays TOO close to the original. All of the levels are in Egypt. You get a wide variety of: open desert, desert with shrines and temples, underground desert temples, and desert favelas. None of the creative, interesting levels from the Second Encounter or Serious Sam 2 make an appearance in this game. As a result, the game gets VERY repetitive in a short amount of time, which is further compounded by the sheer size of levels in Serious Sam games. Much of the humour relies on one-liners and banters, which isn't necessarily a bad thing in itself. However, SS2 went way out of the box and went balls to the wall with silliness, so it's a shame to see 99% of it getting passed over in this rendition. NETRICSA, Sam's in-game guide" so to speak has also been neutered as well
date: offering less information from before and just not worth reading
hoursPlayed: you could read the data sheets of enemies and get a glut of both funny and useful information.\n\nHad there been more level and environment variety with a bit more risk taken

reviewText:
TL;DRAn oldschool FPS with hordes of aliens to annihilate.
+ Intensity
+ Solid mechanics
+ Loads of enemies
+ Vast weaponry
+ Multiplayer
- A bit mind-numbing in longer sessions

REVIEW
Serious Sam 3: BFE is an oldschool FPS with a few modern elements here and there. This game takes the player back to the time when Quake ruled the FPS world: no health regeneration, loadouts*, radar, or quest arrow. Everything one needs to begin the massive extermination of monsters are to be found somewhere in the levels. Moreover, there are tons of secret areas so keep a lookout for them.

The story is very straightforward: the protagonist, Sam Stone, is on a quest to stop the Mental's invasion on Earth. The game is set in Egypt so expect a lot of sandy areas and labyrinths. The player will find a variety of weapons throughout the game: sledgehammer, pistol, shotguns, minigun, explosives, etc. Despite being oldschool overall, the game has the option to aim down sights (ADS), sprint, and manual reload**. Speaking of variety, there are many types of aliens to obliterate, ranging from kamikazes and rocketeers to gnaars and kleer skeletons. The game can be very intense and I do not recommend long sessions, for it may become a bit mind-numbing.

Apart from the single player campaign, the game features a co-op (up to 16 players) campaign, survival, and PvP multiplayer. It is important to keep in mind that the more the players there are in co-op, the stronger the enemies. Survival is a mode where the players have to defend themselves from waves of aliens and the PvP multiplayer features classic modes like deathmatch, capture the flag, and so on. It relies on peer-to-peer connection so it may get very laggy.

All in all, I recommend playing this game. The solid mechanics, hordes of enemies, and a wide selection of weaponry provide hours of fun, especially in the co-op mode. It also happens to be on sale fairly often. A 7/10.

*Quake Live is an exception to the franchise.
**There is an achievement for finishing the game ol' style"

reviewText:
Short version: 82%Serious Sam 3: BFE takes us back to the roots of the series with all the elements that made the First Encounter a cult classic: no-nonsense attitude with a perfect dose of nonsense humour; classic weapons from the double-barrel shotgun to the cannon; and tricky level designs filled to the brim with secrets. This game is definitely not for the CoD generation of gamers, but if you ever want to experience what an old-school FPS was like, don’t look further.

Long version:Forget CoD with its corridors, 10-minute long cut scenes, infinite ammo for the only two available weapons, cover systems and magical self-healing. Serious Sam 3: Before First Encounter is an old-school shooter where the levels are non-linear and feature many hidden spots, where your cover is your armour count, where your health is replenished by walking over medkit pickups, and where your large arsenal is only limited by the amount of ammo you can find.
The only modern features BFE uses are the sprint button and limited weapon magazine size– although older gamers and Serious Sam purist can play the game without these, and they are even awarded with an achievement for it.

As the sub-title suggests, BFE is a prequel telling us how Sam travelled back to ancient Egypt at the beginning of First Encounter, so thankfully we can forget about the Sirian Council and all the other stupidity of Serious Sam II. The tone is quite dark– mostly emphasised by the ruined, desolate city landscapes you fight in–, and the bad action movie one-liners and humorous Easter eggs are only meant to ease the tension a little bit.
In other words, BFE is a lot closer to the First Encounter than any other Serious Sam games, probably making it the second best instalment in the whole series.

If it were me, I would recommend buying the first encounter HD, as some the you cant go wrong with a classic

reviewText:
Serious Sam 3: BFE is the latest addition to Serious Sam franchise, still being a horde-based FPS. And it's a prequel to the first game plot-wise, whoop! BFE is abbrovation for Before First Encoutner, they say. It came out in 2011, being made by Croteam. And it's serious!
It also came out for Xbox 360 and PS3. Probably nothing to check out here, maybe it supports less players in multiplayer.

Multiplayer community is still there. They mostly play coop all the time. Coop survival is less played. And you are likely to get Versus game only on some hours, who knows, it's not as liked by general people. No one plays modded version of game.
That, or you can call your friend to play in split-screen anyway.

And yes, you are once again Sam Stone, who is now wearing cool sunglasses. And this time you are going to kill many Mental's minions and maybe rip some eyes. To save the earth! Maybe. As long as you stay serious. Seriously serious!

And yep, it now goes back to more realistical setting than Serious Sam 2. And you know what? It's awesome. It's like exactly what I always wanted the next installment of Serious Sam back when I was a fan of the first game, before Serious Sam 2 destroyed the dreams. I mean, cmon, you get to play Serious Sam prequel where you shoot kamikazes in ruined town. It's awesome!

And music is still awesome and atmospheric, though this time more forgettable. And scenes are epic. And graphics are great.

Then again, some complain that it might be a bit too serious. But I think it's on same level as The First Encounter. It's belivable plot combined with jokish secrets. And small details. That, and yes, it also has dark tomb levels where player even has slower movement speed, being interesting to explore for a change. No worries, it's not Doom 3. And I can agrue that it brought back memories of the third level of First Encounter which is part of what I liked as well. So I am very happy as a fan here.

It also added some more of modern gameplay elements into it. At least this is what our usual gamers would call them. But they aren't used as much as one might think and mostly is true only for low-tier weapons.  You can aim with assault rifle and pistol down the sight, which slows you down but makes accuaricy perfect. No worries, minigun still doesn't require any aiming and is accurate like sniper rifle.

Few guns also require reloading. It actually fits to pistol and Devastator, a fast-shooting 20-ammo-in-mag explosive railgun thing.  For single-barreled shotgun and assault rifle? Not much. It does make early levels more interesting, having to worry about reloading as rare enemy charges at you. But on bad side, they become mroe painful to use in later levels, so you don't want to change from stronger Double-Shotgun and Minigun. Ok, at least Assault Rifle and Minigun use different ammo, so here is at least saving ammo".

But sprinting is actually a very good addition to Serious Sam franchises. Did you ever think "ok
date: so it has good speed during battles and I enjoy these huge levels but once I killed everybody walking from one corner of huge valley to another to get all secrets is soooo boring"? Yep

reviewText:
A little warning to FPS players used to blazing through FPS games fast- this one takes you off the training wheels and throws you into a serious battlefield!

a few tips from a serious vet:

1. keep moving, just about 99% of the cover in the game is destructible, standing still is a BAD idea.
2. If it shoots bullets, kill it first! in fact, kill anything that has a range advantage over your first, unless it's friggin' kleers, those buggers are annoying.
3. The best targets for C4 are as follows: Khnums, scrapjacks, witch-brides, major biomechanoids.
4. firing off a few rockets and switching to the minigun or assault rifle is a surprisingly  good strategy.
5. above all costs, shoot kamikazes first, you'll live to shoot that scrapjack trying to  reduce you to giblets.
6. Be Prepared to die... a lot.

reviewText: Ну, я ждал эту игру 6 лет и вот что разработчики преподнесли.Хотелось бы начать с графики. Её как я и ожидал улучшили, но одно меня огорчило. Движок Serious Engine 3.5 абсолютно кривой и его кривизна заметна. На моменте когда Сэм вырывает глаз гнаару хочется плакать, вид от 3го лица вообще лучше не включать. Если уж делать игру с кооперативом, то надо ж его до ума довести. Смотреть как твой партнёр держит оружие ладошками просто смешно и на то как Сэм передвигается сидя без слёз не взглянешь. Ну если откинуть движок и все его недочёты, то игра получилась очень крутой хоть непродолжительной, всего около 3-6 часов. Разработчикам удалось сохранить ту атмосферу которая была в предыдущих двух частях, когда на тебя бежит толпа разгневанных пришельцев и тебе ничего не остаётся, кроме того чтобы взять миниган и всех их похоронить.Саунтрэк просто сногшибательный, куча новых врагов, куча нового оружия, кооператив на 16 человек, все теже коронные фразочки Сэма, всё это подарило незабываемое удовольствие от игры.Конечно же игра не стоит своих 600 рублей, но на распрадаже по скидкам взять и поиграть с друзьями просто необходимо! Вобщем оценка моя такова 9.7 было бы 10 если бы движок доработали,а так игра крутая всем советую.

reviewText: This looked to be a step in the right direction after SS2 lost its way, but sadly SS3 has not learnt from many of those mistakes. The levels are still mostly made up of corridors and enclosed spaces instead of the glorious open spaces the first two encounters are known for, and SS3 even has you spend a lot of time in the dark with only a flashlight to see.. reviewText:
Serving as a prequel to the original indie sensation, Serious Sam: The First Encounter, Serious Sam 3: BFE takes place during the Earth's final struggle against Mental's invading legions of beasts and mercenaries.

The story, as it were, is pretty thin. It's the future. Mankind has gone off into space. Evil aliens are ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off. Earth has been invaded. Humans are screwed. Sam is humanity's last hope. He doesn't give a damn, he's good with a gun, and high explosives are the perfect solution to most of his problems. Most of the dialogue is corny with a side helping of heavy cheese, but there are a few laughs sprinkled throughout. The game isn't afraid to poke fun at genre conventions, and Sam is more or less a self-aggrandizing caricature of the buff dumb hero" stereotype.

Most of the enemies are familiar
recommended: laser-spewing Biomechanoids and vicious Kleer skeletons returning with their familiar attacks in place. Every enemy has been redesigned to make them look more detestable and even disturbing than ever.\n\nSerious Sam 3: BFE is not a game for the faint of heart. It will challenge your resolve while it constantly pushes you back under a tidal wave of skeletons
hoursPlayed: fireballs
voteText: rockets and chaingun-wielding scorpions. Its levels can last up to an hour
helpfulPercent: its gameplay never deviates from one note
votesHelpful: and it will cause players to thump their desks and roar with rage
votesTotal: but it's so much fun."

reviewText: Where do I start? The game had poor voice acting, even worse dialogue. The cutscenes sucked, but I was stunned when they ended. For when the actual game started, I was exposed to some of the worst gameplay I've ever seen. Throughout the game, you shoot everything that moves, no matter what it is. The enemy AI sucks, the difficulty is pathetic. You can melee enemies from very far away. The games selling point seems to be for unintelligent people who like games where without any skill involved, they get to kill hundreds of enemies in explosively gorey fasions. I'm surprised this is actually a game.

reviewText:
Serving as a prequel to the original indie sensation, Serious Sam: The First Encounter, Serious Sam 3: BFE takes place during the Earth's final struggle against Mental's invading legions of beasts and mercenaries.

The story, as it were, is pretty thin. It's the future. Mankind has gone off into space. Evil aliens are ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off. Earth has been invaded. Humans are screwed. Sam is humanity's last hope. He doesn't give a damn, he's good with a gun, and high explosives are the perfect solution to most of his problems. Most of the dialogue is corny with a side helping of heavy cheese, but there are a few laughs sprinkled throughout. The game isn't afraid to poke fun at genre conventions, and Sam is more or less a self-aggrandizing caricature of the buff dumb hero" stereotype.

Most of the enemies are familiar
recommended: laser-spewing Biomechanoids and vicious Kleer skeletons returning with their familiar attacks in place. Every enemy has been redesigned to make them look more detestable and even disturbing than ever.\n\nSerious Sam 3: BFE is not a game for the faint of heart. It will challenge your resolve while it constantly pushes you back under a tidal wave of skeletons
hoursPlayed: fireballs
voteText: rockets and chaingun-wielding scorpions. Its levels can last up to an hour
helpfulPercent: its gameplay never deviates from one note
votesHelpful: and it will cause players to thump their desks and roar with rage
votesTotal: but it's so much fun."

When duke nukem fails, BFE wins.
Bfe is as funny as its predecessor. As usual don't expect a good storyline.
The whole new style is nice, the soundtrack too but of course, some new features disgusted me.

Secondly, WHERE'S THE CHAINSAW?! How in the hellthe hammer can be a good replacement?! Where are the dual colts? Where's the thompson? Where's the good old shotgun who only needed to pump after each shot and didn't necessite any reload?
The melee system is a big joke, when you're surrounded by ennemies it won't help you at all.

Of course, this game is far from bad bad but, eh, I can't get used to some of the new thing. Fortunately, the workshop is here..

reviewText: Oh ♥♥♥♥, is that some mother♥♥♥♥ing Serious Sam 3? You bet your ♥♥♥ it is. Take your  slow ♥♥♥ warfare realism and deep moral choices elsewhere, you're about to take on a hundred ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s all at once and you're all outta rockets. Fire a cannonball into an alien bull's face and take on a biomech walker with just a sledgehammer. You've got a campaign, multiplayer, coop, survival, and all kindsa stuff to test your mettle against. It ain't the best Sam game, but it's still a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Serious Sam game. Combat can be frustrating with odd hitboxes and the occasional clumsy pathfinding, and you're probably going to get sick of the Egyptian motif by the end of it, but this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ is still going to be a blast from start to end. Don't feed the kleers.

reviewText:
If you want a classic fps in the form of better graphics then this is definitely for you.

Singleplayer:
Same as multiplayer, except without humans playing with you. Story is admitidly a bit crap and boring but yeah.
It is (as you might've noticed) in fact kinda a ripoff of doom. But just because its a copy doesnt mean its good :P.
Overall singleplayer is pretty good.

Multiplayer:
Awesome, its much more fun to ♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ up with your friends than singleplayer. Play Co-Op through the singleplayer campaign. Or make the last stand in Survival trying to beat your highscore. Only minor problem with multiplayer is that theres not many servers anymore since this game was made back in 2011 :(.

Modable Version:
Same as original game but with mods. Only downside is that you can't play with other people.

7/10 Above Average, not the best game...but a classic.

reviewText:
You liked the first Serious Sam? Yes? Then get this one (or at least think about buying when it's on sale). Great old-school-shooter. Countless enemies to kill, wave after wave, it won't stop, your trigger-finger will hurt, your eyes will bleed, you will get stomped, shot down, get blown away by your own C4, get lasered, get kicked away by alien cows, you will surf alien cows, will kill nude witches and harpys and finally, you'll find the cannon gun and make the earth crumble. Starts off kind of slow with some rather ugly levels but then transforms into the old fun we once knew from the first part of the series: beautiful, vast desert areas full of primitive, mindless shooting (and egyptian monuments to destroy). But don't let the word 'primitive' fool you. The game can be quite challenging in some parts and on harder difficulty, at least some tactical approach is needed, especially when playing alone. Of course, one of the greatest aspects of Serious Sam was and still is the Co-Op. The more the merrier! Deathmatch and other PvP is also fun, but hard to find nowadays and nothing you can/should play competitive. All in all, serious fun!

PRO
beautiful desert areas
great number of enemies at once
old-school shooter gameplay
great co-op game
good replay value due to extra modes (survival etc.) and challenging difficulties
CON
it has a story and cutscenes (no one needed that)
Sams one-liner could be better
some levels (especially the first ones) are not so good

reviewText:
Great old school shooter with running gun ablazing. Trade the subtlety of modern FPSs with pure adrenaline rush. No cover, no health recovery, no taking sissy break every 30 seconds.

Beautiful graphics and intense sound design make you feel manly and powerful.

Some dry sense of humor that some might find offensive.

Overall good to pick up and play once a while for pure silly fun.

reviewText: Serious Sam in all his glory. The story is decent, the graphics are pretty awesome but more importantly the gameplay is fun. Hordes upon hordes of crazier than crazy enemies running right at you in an attempt to do the impossible: kill Serious Sam. The game is fairly difficult on the default setting, making it a nice challenge. Just get through the first few levels and you'll start seeing the old school shooter that this game really is. The only issue I could mention is the length and perhaps the pacing. The single player campaign takes about 10-12 hours - and the first few hours are very slow, compared to the rest. Playing through the game on different difficulties could make it last longer and there is a survival mode, not to mention multiplayer. It's a solid game altogether, especially if you're a fan of the series. Last but not least...\n\nIt's time to get serious!

reviewText:
This is a game for people that like to crush, kill and destroy. it is also for people that save a lot and are not afraid to die a lot. It is plain hard to advance in this game. Even in the first levels there are parts with so many enemies that you get out of ammo really fast.

I hate the running Kleer skeletons, since they are not easy to kill, are fast and take a lot of life when hitting you. and the fact that they jump and have a long range attack is even worst.

The game has a lot of jokes, and Sam sometimes says nice catchphrases and comments about the situation. The story is basically kill everything until you finish the level. In a few parts it is necessary to collect some keys to advance.

The best of the game is actually the cannon. There is no better friend than a cannon when in tight corridors with many enemies coming your way.

the game also features the melee attacks, which are somewhat gruesome, but interesting to use in the few moments that you are not fighting 20 enemies or more at once.

It is a good game to spend a few hours finishing.

reviewText: Stupid. Testosterone-filled. Pointless. Crude.\nThese are a few words that come to mind when I played Duke Nukem, I mean Serious Sam. The humor is low-brow, the action is arcad-ie and relentless, and the protagonist’s voice, dear God. Everyone in this game has a voice actor but he has a lawn mower. This game feels like it was deliberately terrible and I think that is what makes it enjoyable. Once again, playing with friends is the only way, this time you can have 15 of ‘em with you! I do enjoy playing this game due to its instantly gratifying nature and lack of actual investment.\n6/10

reviewText:
Serious Sam 3: BFE takes places before the events of Serious Sam 1 First Encounter and Second Encounter. The game sticks to it's roots which is a mindless shoot'em up arena shooter. Shoot all the enemies, to move on. Lots of loot to be found and secrets to be explored. The game is not too closely related to Serious Sam 2.  GREAT co-op game.

No graphical issues for me.
Multiplayer is a bit bare, which is a shame it's lot of fun.
Difficulty is a wide range, not on ly do you have something like 5-7 difficulty settings, you can tweak the difficulty and make it even harder in co-op.

Similar Games: Painkiller.
If you like SS3 make sure to check out the rest of the series.
Has tools for you to make your own content
